Title: Boulder Falcon, LLC v. Brown
Court: United States District Court, D. Utah.
Headnote: Defendants' counterclaims against limited liability company's (LLC) agent and corporation for open account, promissory estoppel, quantum meruit, and unjust enrichment under Utah law, which arose from dispute over shared ownership of aircraft and were premised on alter ego liability, were not barred by statute of frauds and parol evidence rule; equitable theory of alter ego was conceptually unrelated from party's promise to answer for debt of another, whether court could, in its inherent power, fashion appropriate remedy for legal wrongs by disregarding corporate form was unrelated to regulation of private parties' promises to one another, and counterclaims were not premised on existence of any guaranty agreement. Utah Code Ann. § 25-5-4(1)(a).
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Genuine disputes of material fact precluded summary judgment in favor of defendants on LLC's claim for breach of contract under Georgia law.

Title: Estate of Ewers
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: There was no evidence that mining company was alter ego of owner of interest in company, even though there was some evidence that owner used company funds improperly by transferring money from company's checking account into an account owner used for both personal and business expenses; owner was not sole owner, and transfers were unauthorized.

Title: Boobuli's LLC v. State Farm General Insurance Company
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, insurer's parent corporation could not be held liable on alter ego theory in insured's suit alleging that insurer failed to properly adjust premiums for its business risk policies despite unavoidable decrease in insured's business operations due to COVID pandemic, absent evidence that insurer was inadequately capitalized and failure to disregard separate identities corporate would result in fraud or injustice.

Title: Lentner v. Upstate Forestry and Development, LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: Piercing of timber company's corporate veil to hold company's owner personally liable was not warranted, in action arising out of timber sale contract between company and property owner for breach of contract, fraud, violation of statute prohibiting unauthorized cutting of timber, conversion, and unjust enrichment, where company owner was acting on behalf of company at all relevant times, and did not engage in acts amounting to abuse or perversion of corporate form warranting piercing of veil. N.Y. RPAPL § 861.

Title: Michigan GeoSearch, Inc. v. TC Energy Corporation
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Piercing corporate veil was not warranted under Michigan law to allow owner of natural gas well to seek recovery from parent company of owner of natural gas storage field, in well owner's action against parent company based on allegations that natural gas was migrating from field to well; parent company never owned or operated field, field owner never granted parent company storage rights, state and federal agencies recognized and issued permits to field owner as owner and operator of field, statements on companies' websites about companies' relationship were consistent with parent-subsidiary relationship, and alleged fraudulent and wrongful conduct of field owner related only to field owner's own actions, rather than parent company's use of field owner.

Title: Malaro v. Wilkie
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, fact that contractor was president and sole officer of corporation did not constitute "pervasive control" in support of piercing corporate veil, and, thus, homeowners could not maintain their claims against contractor in his individual capacity for breach of contract, fraudulent misrepresentation, conversion, and breach of implied warranty of good workmanship, arising from renovations that homeowners hired contractor to perform at their residence.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Fact that contractor was president and sole officer of corporation did not constitute pervasive control in support of piercing corporate veil.

Title: Certain Underwriters at Lloyds v. CSX Transportation, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Illinois.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, insurer for shipper of locomotives demonstrated a unity of ownership and interest between first railroad company, which was headquartered in Kentucky, and second railroad company, which operated railroads in Illinois, as required to pierce the corporate veil to confer personal jurisdiction over first company, in action for damages associated with train derailment; companies shared directors and officers, and companies entered management agreement, whereby second company's customer could use first company's internet booking service.
Document Preview: TRANSPORTATION  Railroads. Railroad company did not provide a service through its railway booking website, as required for liability under the Interstate Commerce Act.

Title: Certain Underwriters at Lloyds v. CSX Transportation, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Illinois.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, insurer for shipper of locomotives failed to demonstrate that the adherence to the fiction of separate corporate existence of first railroad company, which was headquartered in Kentucky, and second railroad company, which operated railroads in Illinois, would sanction fraud or promote injustice, as required to pierce the corporate veil to confer personal jurisdiction over first company, in action for damages associated with train derailment; first company's presence in the action was not required to prevent an unjust outcome, as there was no evidence that second company was anything other than an adequately capitalized corporation, suggesting that insurer could recover against second company.
Document Preview: TRANSPORTATION  Railroads. Railroad company did not provide a service through its railway booking website, as required for liability under the Interstate Commerce Act.

Title: Sacred Heart Health Services v. MMIC Insurance, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. South Dakota, Southern Division.
Headnote: Allegations by insured health system and surgery center that involvement of liability insurer's parent company in insurer's purported deceit and bad-faith conduct in process of settling underlying tort actions against insureds rendered it inequitable or unjust to adhere to fiction of corporate separateness were sufficient to state claim for breaching of corporate veil under South Dakota law, where insureds alleged that parent company's chief legal officer made unconditional offer for insurer to contribute $2 million to global settlement of underlying actions, that insurer, through such officer, suppressed the fact that insurer had no intention to perform on such promise, and that insurer failed to disclose that contribution would be contingent on waiver of bad-faith claims against insurer. S.D. Codified Laws § 20-10-2(4).
Document Preview: INSURANCE  Liability. Liability insurer's alleged defense under reservation of rights agreement could permit insureds to bind insurer to reasonable settlement.

Title: Disciplinary Counsel v. Nordic Title Agency, Inc., and Hall
Court: Supreme Court of Ohio.
Headnote: Evidence was insufficient to establish president of company engaged in the unauthorized practice of law, and thus disciplinary counsel could not pierce the corporate veil and hold president responsible for the acts of company's employees in preparing and filing deeds to real property that were not reviewed by an attorney; president did not prepare any of the deeds or affidavits at issue, and company's policy was that all deeds and legal instruments had to be reviewed by an attorney.
Document Preview: LEGAL SERVICES  Unauthorized Practice. Civil penalty of $10,000 was warranted for title company's unauthorized practice of law by preparing and recording deeds to transfer title to real property.

Title: Liberty Highrise Pvt. Ltd. v. Praxis Energy Agents DMCC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Maritime vessel operator adequately alleged that Singapore company was alter ego of Dubai company sufficient to pierce the corporate veil of Singapore company in action for breach of contract, conversion, and unjust enrichment alleging companies wrongfully retained payment for bunker; though operator did not allege fraud, operator alleged overlap in both leadership and ownership of companies, same individual acted as legal advisor to both companies and communicated on behalf of both companies from same email address, sole shareholder of Singapore company was manager of Dubai company, both companies conducted the same type of business and sold same type of products under same terms and conditions, and companies shared the same internet domain name.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW  Jurisdiction. Maritime vessel operator made prima facie showing of personal jurisdiction over Dubai company and Singapore company sufficient to defeat motion to dismiss.

Title: Hanamura-Valashinas v. Transitions by Firenza, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eleventh District, Lake County.
Headnote: Managing partner and part-owner of construction company did not exercise control so complete over company that it had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, and therefore corporate form of company could not be disregarded and managing partner and part-owner, as shareholders, could not be held liable for wrongs committed by company. (Per Lynch, J., with two judges concurring in judgment only.)
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Allegation by homeowners that managing partner falsified invoices before presenting them violated duty independent of construction agreement.

Title: Saks Management and Associates, LLC v. Sung General Contracting, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Evidence that construction contractor's business account was used to pay contractor's owner's personal credit-card bills and personal expenses and that owner transferred money between his personal and various business bank accounts was insufficient to warrant piercing contractor's corporate veil, absent evidence showing that the expenses were not legitimate business expenses or authorized by the corporation as part of owner's compensation.

Title: Carter v. City of Montgomery
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Alabama, Northern Division.
Headnote: Probation services company was not the alter ego of its principal company, as would establish successor liability for principal company by piercing the corporate veil based on excessive control in probationer's § 1983 against city and probation company, who entered into contract with city to supervise misdemeanor probation for those on municipal court-ordered probation, alleging violations of due process, equal protection, and the Fourth, Sixth, and Eighth Amendments for their involvement in municipal court's systemic practice of jailing traffic offenders for failing to pay fines without inquiring into their ability to pay; the record lacked evidence that principal company misused whatever control it had over probation company. U.S. Const. Amends. 4, 6, 8, 14; 42 U.S.C.A. § 1983.
Document Preview: CIVIL RIGHTS  Due Process. Issue of fact existed whether city knew and was deliberately indifferent to company requesting probation revocation despite no willful failure to pay fines.

Title: Hipps v. Biglari Holdings, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Corporate alter ego doctrine did not permit minority shareholders to assert that corporation and limited partnerships of which corporation was majority limited partner were effectively same entity for purposes of treating partnerships' acquisition of corporation's shares as corporation's reacquisition of its own shares; purpose of corporate alter ego theory was to prevent a company from using an interrelated company to escape liability, not to determine whether company effectively reacquired its shares such that shares should have been considered nonvoting. Ind. Code Ann. § 23-1-27-2(a).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Shareholders. Sole remedy for shareholders' merger-related claims of breach of fiduciary duty and unjust enrichment was to sell shares on open market.

Title: Union Telecom, LLC v. United States
Court: United States Court of Federal Claims.
Headnote: Telecommunications carrier did not exercise complete domination of corporation which resold carrier's prepaid long-distance telephone cards, and thus reseller was not alter ego of carrier; although carrier owned 51% of reseller and had right to appoint most of reseller's senior leadership, including its president, chief financial officer (CFO), and chief operating officer (COO), in practice individual who owned remaining 49% controlled reseller, managing day-to-day operations, making all final decisions, and excluding carrier-appointed leadership from meetings, and carrier and reseller otherwise filed separate tax returns, maintained own records, handled own accounts payable and receivable, occupied separate offices, maintained own bank accounts, and prepared own financial statements.
Document Preview: TAXATION  Excise. Presumption that telecommunications carrier included excise tax in prepaid phone cards' price paid by first non-carrier to buy cards was rebutted.

Title: McKay v. Longman
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Prejudice to innocent equity holders or creditors did not weigh against allowing judgment creditor's outsider reverse veil piercing of three limited liability companies (LLC) and one corporation; one LLC's creditors appeared to be secured creditors, and while judgment debtor's wife was an equity holder in the entities, she received her ownership interests for no consideration and she gave judgment debtor full and effectively sole authority to make decisions for the entities and gave affirmative authorization to judgment debtor's conduct in his attempt to avoid his creditors.

Title: Sabre GLBL, Inc v. Shan
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, doctrine of corporate separateness, pursuant to which individual could incorporate business and shield himself from personal liability for corporation's obligations, did not apply to shield former employee from personal liability for her own misappropriation of employer's clients, staff, and confidential information and trade secrets and breach of fiduciary duty by starting competing business while still working for employer; employee's misconduct not only benefited her competing business by giving it two-year development and operations head start but also benefited employee personally by increasing value of her ownership interest in business, and therefore, there was no need to pierce company's corporate veil to require employee to disgorge value she personally received as result of her misconduct.
Document Preview: TORTS  Alternative Dispute Resolution. Arbitrator did not manifestly disregard Texas law governing award of head start disgorgement damages, as basis for vacatur of arbitration award.

Title: Innerimages, Inc. v. Newman
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee, AT KNOXVILLE.
Headnote: Piercing of the corporate veil was appropriate and gated-community developer's president was personally liable for damages incurred by developer in action by homeowners for breach of fiduciary duty, where president was sole shareholder of developer, developer issued no stock certificates, developer's office was president's home, and developer and president shared same attorneys and hired same employees to perform lawn care and maintenance services.

Headnote: Financial and investment advisor's claims that foreign corporation served as his client's alter ego were merely a means to hold the corporation responsible for client's conduct and, thus, did not provide a basis to hold corporation liable for any of the conduct alleged against it.

Title: Riley v. Barringer
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Virginia, Abingdon Division.
Headnote: Former employee did not allege facts sufficient for district court to infer that the separate personalities of employer and its sole shareholder no longer existed or that employer was shareholder's alter ego, as required, under Virginia law, to state claims, including unjust enrichment and fraud, against shareholder personally, arising from, inter alia, employer's alleged failure to reimburse funds that employee purportedly deposited in employer's bank account from her own retirement account and personal funds; allegations did not suggest that shareholder personally guaranteed the alleged loan that employee made, allegations did not suggest shareholder personally benefited from loan, there was no evidence shareholder treated employer's funds as his own, and employee's remaining causes of action only mentioned shareholder's name.

Title: Williams v. National Gallery , London
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Entity had no liability as alter ego of British national museum, in action by legal heirs of former owner of painting by Henri Matisse who sought to recover painting from museum, which had acquired painting after it was allegedly sold without owner's authorization when she departed from Ally-occupied Berlin in aftermath of World War II; entity had not even allegedly been used by museum to harm heirs.

Title: City of Cleveland v. Embassy Realty Investments, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth District, Cuyahoga County.
Headnote: President of corporation had such a level of control over corporation which owned property on which building was demolished that corporation was indistinguishable from or alter ego of president and, thus, city could recover its costs for demolition of building from president; corporation was undercapitalized in that president put his own money into the property and received personal loan for improvements to the property prior to transferring the property to corporation, only corporate formality observed was filing of articles of incorporation, corporation kept minimal corporate records and had no separate bank account, and third-party lease payments to maintain a billboard on property continued to be paid to president personally after corporation purchased the property from president.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Judgment. Issue of whether president held control over corporation to unlawfully maintain nuisance on its property precluded summary judgment in action for demolition costs.

Title: Gowen v. Helly Nahmad Gallery, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York.
Headnote: Ancillary administrator for estate of original and allegedly rightful owner of painting that was taken by Nazis during occupation of Paris sufficiently alleged that art dealership was alter ego of dealership owner, such that trial court could pierce the corporate veil and exercise personal jurisdiction over owner, in administrator's replevin action seeking return of painting, where administrator alleged that owner held all stock in dealership, that dealership failed to adhere to corporate formalities such as keeping regular books and records, failed to generate income, and failed to have an independent board of directors, and that dealership was underfunded, such that administrator would be unable to recover reasonable costs if successful on claim. N.Y. CPLR §§ 302(a)(1), 302(a)(2).
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Replevin. New York was not inconvenient forum for replevin action seeking return of painting taken by Nazis during occupation of Paris.

Title: Morello v. State
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Austin.
Headnote: The principle that an individual can incorporate a business and thereby shield himself from personal liability is subject to exceptions in circumstances in which maintaining the corporate shield would result in injustice and inequity, including situations involving fraud, evasions of existing obligations, circumvention of statutes, monopolization, criminal conduct, and other similar behavior.

Title: Hawes v. Kabani & Company, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Washington.
Headnote: Claim that managing principal of an auditing corporation participated in the audit of a Washington company, and that principal approved the use of the audit in the company's securities filings, sufficiently alleged that principal participated in an audit challenged as factually inaccurate, as required to pierce the corporate veil and state claims of negligent and intentional misrepresentation, violation of Washington state securities laws, and unjust enrichment against principal.

Title: In re ES2 Sports & Leisure, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. North Carolina, Greensboro Division.
Headnote: Under North Carolina law, individual who was officer, director and majority owner of Chapter 7 debtor's parent company had control and complete domination of company in both its finances and business practices, warranting piercing the corporate veil under instrumentality rule, where company was inadequately capitalized and had a number of months in which it was either completely insolvent or had extremely thin capitalization, there was a non-compliance with corporate formalities, including failure to file an annual report with the North Carolina Secretary of State's office for certain year and failure to maintain a current/active registered agent, and checks had been issued to individual to pay personal utility bill, student loan, and personal cable bill.

Headnote: Two Irish companies, one of which was transferee of transferor's non-sports prediction markets and technology-related intellectual property pursuant to transferor's deconsolidation, operated as common enterprise, and thus, after the transfer, transferor company still had customers, so that transferor company, based transferee company's offering of prediction-related binary options to United States customers through websites, violated consent order between transferor and Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC); companies had same directors and officers, they shared office space, and they commingled funds, with transferor maintaining bank accounts that accepted funds from United States customers. Commodity Exchange Act § 6c, 7 U.S.C.A. § 13a-1.

Title: Northwest Cascade, Inc. v. Unique Const., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 2.
Headnote: Piercing of the corporate veil, thereby allowing contractor that obtained judgment against corporation to seek recovery from shareholders, did not entitle shareholders to claim a homestead exemption in property, which was owned by the corporation and on which the shareholders were living; allowing shareholders to have a homestead exemption would not have served the purpose of adjusting allocation of loss between creditor and persons who misused the corporate form, nor would it have rectified an abuse of the corporate privilege. West's RCWA 6.13.040(1).

Title: Queens West Development Corp. v. Nixbot Realty Associates
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: In condemnation proceeding, petitioner failed to show that claimants abused corporate form, as required to pierce corporate veil with respect to their company that operated tennis club on subject property and their property management company, or that property should be treated as owner-occupied under alter-ego theory, and thus awarding club just compensation for taking of trade fixtures was warranted, separate from award to claimants for taking of fee; even though claimants' deposition indicated failure to adhere to some corporate formalities, there was no indication that either company was undercapitalized, that they commingled assets, or that claimants appropriated funds of either for personal use, both companies were formed at separate times and for separate, legitimate purposes, and bona fide lease existed between companies. Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: In dispute over ownership of funds in deposit account opened by former Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia's (SFRY) Federal Directorate of Supply and Management (FDSP), pursuant to interpretive rules set forth in Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties, alter-ego analysis neither applied to determination of whether FDSP was SFRY "agency" within meaning of agreement that required SFRY agencies to distribute funds to SFRY successor states, nor overcame presumption of independence afforded to foreign sovereign; FDSP's assumedly corporate form did not shield it from succession agreement, no third-party sought redress, and alter-ego analysis was relied upon solely to shield instrumentality from foreign state that owned it. Title: Johnson v. Ross
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Absent evidence warranting piercing the corporate veil, West Virginia law precluded licensors from recovering, on a theory of unjust enrichment, from corporate licensee's controlling shareholder the benefit shareholder received by virtue of the increased value of licensee's stock due to technical assistance provided by licensors; assuming that licensors' technical assistance was valuable, that value was realized by corporate licensee, the company undertaking to improve licensor's technology, rather than by shareholder individually, and the value of the confidential technology disclosed to licensee's employees could not be said to have been conferred on shareholder, and thus he was not the unjust recipient of the value of that technology.

Title: Kromrey v. Ali
Court: Court of Appeals of Minnesota.
Headnote: District court abused its discretion in holding nonshareholder personally liable for corporation's debts when the corporate veil was pierced. Minn.Stat. § 302A.425 (2010).

Headnote: Under Michigan law, corporation's veil would be pierced and judgment entered against an owner's new company; the owner's failure to inject any capital into the company more than a year after its founding, the fact that it did not have a bank account, and the fact that it had not engaged in ordinary business transactions, were all factors that militated very strongly in favor of piercing the corporation's veil, and of equal importance was the fact that the company was created by the owner while the instant litigation was pending.

Title: Gregorie v. Alpine Meadows Ski Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. California.
Headnote: Parent company, who approved major projects over subsidiary, did not exert the degree of control necessary to reasonably deem the subsidiary an agent of the parent, thus parent company was not liable for acts or omissions of the subsidiary. Title: Citgo Petroleum Corp. v. Ranger Enterprises, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Wisconsin.
Headnote: Petroleum distribution franchisee failed to allege that Venezuelan president was acting as an officer of state-owned franchisor when he made anti-American comments, which allegedly breached an implied duty not to impair value of franchisor's brand, although some of franchisee's customers allegedly boycotted franchisee's gas stations as a result of comments, and thus franchisee was not entitled to pierce corporate veil to make franchisor vicariously liable for comments.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Petroleum Marketing Practices Act. Gas station franchisee did not reasonably rely on statement of franchisor's representative, which at most modified agreement.

Title: Academy of Skills & Knowledge, Inc. v. Charter Schools, USA, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Tyler.
Headnote: Charter school did not have an agent-principal relationship with the parent corporation of the management company with which charter school formed a management contract, precluding school's breach of fiduciary duty claim against the parent corporation, even though the parent corporation was a party to the contract, where parent corporation's representative signed the contract with an express, written indication that it was only signing as to certain provisions, and such provisions did not grant or impose any rights or obligations upon the parent corporation.
Document Preview: EDUCATION - Property and Contracts. Charter school's negligence claims were barred by the economic loss rule.

Title: In re Pharmaceutical Industry Average Wholesale Price Litigation
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Pharmaceutical company's parent company could not be held liable for wrongful acts of pharmaceutical company in relator's qui tam action under False Claims Act, absent evidence which supported piercing corporate veil. 31 U.S.C.A. §§ 3729-3733.

Title: Fisher v. Zaks
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Piercing of corporate veil was not warranted, absent evidence that corporation's owners exercised complete domination of the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue, that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against plaintiff, resulting in injury, that corporation was insolvent, or that improper conveyances were made. McKinney's Debtor and Creditor Law §§ 271-276.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil was not warranted, absent evidence of complete domination of corporation.

Title: Ivanov v. Sunset Pools Management Inc.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Natural person was not alter ego of alleged malfeasant corporation on basis that person was part-owner of corporation, and thus corporate veil could not be pierced under District of Columbia law, since corporation was adequately capitalized, funds had not been commingled, and person did not personally make use of corporation to perpetuate fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Natural person was not alter ego of alleged malfeasant corporation on basis that person was part-owner of corporation.

Title: Albright v. Attorney's Title Ins. Fund
Court: United States District Court, D. Utah, Central Division.
Headnote: Reinsurance treaty between majority stockholder of title insurance company and title insurance company did not demonstrate a lack of separateness nor provide stockholder with excessive control over company as to satisfy first prong of alter ego theory, as required to justify piercing the corporate veil; treaty was in effect before stockholder purchased an interest in company and while the treaty provided stockholder with reasonable oversight of reinsurance-related issues, it did not allow the parent to control company's day-to-day operations.
Document Preview: TORTS - RICO. Company executive vice president's actions attempting to cover up fraud did not cause fraud as to support private RICO claim.

Title: Albright v. Attorney's Title Ins. Fund
Court: United States District Court, D. Utah, Central Division.
Headnote: Allegations that title insurance company was undercapitalized were insufficient to show injustice or inequity under the second prong of alter ego test, as to require piercing of the corporate veil between company and its majority stockholder, where evidence showed majority stockholder provided financial assistance to company when the company could not satisfy its obligations.
Document Preview: TORTS - RICO. Company executive vice president's actions attempting to cover up fraud did not cause fraud as to support private RICO claim.

Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: Upon incorporation of trust assets, the corporation becomes the alter ego of the trustees and as such, the propriety of the trustee's acts must be determined in the light of the trust and must be controlled by the provisions of the trust.
Document Preview: ESTATE PLANNING AND PROBATE - Trusts. Decision by trustees serving on trust's holding company's board to sell farm was not protected by business judgment rule.

Title: Shepherd Montessori Center Milan v. Ann Arbor Charter Tp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan.
Headnote: Doctrine of piercing the corporate veil was not applicable to zoning dispute between township board of zoning appeals and parochial school, in which school alleged that board's denial of its request for a variance to operate a faith-based primary school placed a substantial burden on school's religious exercise, in violation of Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act (RLUIPA), as it could not be reasonably argued that board suffered an unjust injury or loss by any alleged fraud by school, nor was there any showing of fraud or wrongdoing. Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, subsidiary was not the alter ego of parent corporation's sole shareholder; subsidiary engaged in corporate formalities, had officers and employees other than shareholder, was adequately capitalized, and subsidiary's assets as his own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Parent corporation was not liable for judgment against subsidiary.

Title: Pottschmidt v. Klosterman
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Ninth District, Medina County.
Headnote: Alter-ego doctrine was satisfied, as would support piercing corporate veil of original and new corporations; sole shareholder had complete control over both corporations, shareholder did not follow corporate formalities, funds of corporations and shareholders were commingled, and vehicle, which was titled in original corporation's name, was used personally by shareholder.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Alter-ego doctrine was satisfied for purposes of piercing corporate veil.

Title: Laborers' Pension Fund v. Lay-Com, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, "promoting injustice" prong of test for piercing corporate veil was satisfied as to successor construction business, as required for predecessor's liabilities to attach to company that coordinated predecessor's dissolution and successor's incorporation; through series of structured transactions effecting dissolution/incorporation, company acquired $1.2 million of predecessor's contract receivables and materials in exchange for forgiving loans amounting to fraction of that, while purportedly assuming $1.5 million in liabilities that it then passed to successor, an undercapitalized shell corporation.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Collective Bargaining. Company was successor to dissolved entity, and bound by its union agreements, given identity of successor's operations.

Title: Laborers' Pension Fund v. Lay-Com, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, company that served as conduit in series of structured transactions that effected dissolution of predecessor construction business and incorporation of under-capitalized successor was subject to predecessor's liabilities once successor's corporate veil was pierced, even though it was not shareholder in successor; there was no legitimate purpose behind company's inextricable involvement, and at end of transactions company failed to honor even the artificial structure they had created.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Collective Bargaining. Company was successor to dissolved entity, and bound by its union agreements, given identity of successor's operations.

Title: Laborers' Pension Fund v. Lay-Com, Inc.

Headnote: Under Illinois law, trust that was sole shareholder in companies that conducted series of structured transactions that effected dissolution of predecessor construction business and incorporation of under-capitalized successor was potentially subject to predecessor's liabilities once successor's corporate veil was pierced, even though it was not directly involved in transactions; trust made number of direct payments to successor during its life span, with no evidence of any loan or other documentation, that enabled successor to continue its fragile existence, thus facilitating effort to deprive predecessor's obligees of their entitlement.

Title: Laborers' Pension Fund v. Lay-Com, Inc.

Headnote: Under total control test for imposing lender liability on lender corporation, control inquiry is whether the debtor corporation is little more than a legal fiction, and fundamental unfairness must be shown to exist.

Title: Intek Auto Leasing, Inc. v. Gharib
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate Division.
Headnote: Corporate president and sole shareholder of truck repair corporation that was in possession of truck pursuant to bailment was not individually liable to bailor for damage to vehicle; corporation was engaged in the business of selling and repairing trucks, bailor always dealt with corporation under its corporate name, and there was no proof of fraud or injustice.

Headnote: Corporation's former Chief Financial Officer (CFO) could not hold its former chairman individually liable on alter ego grounds, where evidence presented does not demonstrate that damages resulted from misuse of the corporate form.

Title: Secrest v. Gibbs

Headnote: President of corporations involved in property development had no functional control over the corporations and delegated all decision making to her husband, and thus, she could not be held personally liable for actions of corporations under a theory of piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Shareholder's wife, who was corporate president, was not personally liable for actions of corporations.

Title: In re Summers
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Mere fact that wife's business operated out of same building previously used as place of business by her husband's company, that companies had nearly identical names and conducted substantially similar business, and that telephone number for wife's business was same telephone number previously used by husband's company was insufficient, without more, to permit piercing of corporate veil under Michigan law.

Court: United States District Court, D. Oregon.
Headnote: Under Oregon law, corporate veil of parent corporation would not be pierced to hold corporation liable for alleged wrongful acts of division of independent subsidiary corporation, absent allegation that parent engaged in any improper conduct in its control over division or that plaintiffs were unable to obtain adequate remedy against division and subsidiary.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Parent corporation was not liable for alleged wrongdoing of subsidiary division.

Title: Cosgrove Distributors, Inc. v. Haff
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Third District.
Headnote: Piercing of the corporate veil of restaurant supply wholesale corporation was not warranted; the two shareholders held annual meetings, thereby maintaining corporate formalities, they did not commingle their funds with those of the corporation, they did not borrow from the corporation, and they did not loan money to the corporation, and the corporation had employees, customers, and suppliers and was a separate and distinct commercial enterprise.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Shareholders were not equitably estopped from asserting corporate status.

Title: Murdock v. Ventures Trident II
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Owner of silica sand mine failed to establish alter ego relationship between corporation that held majority equitable interest in joint venture that leased mine and limited partnership that held minority shareholder interest in corporation, so as to hold partnership liable for mine's failure; although owner demonstrated close business relationship with some overlap in personnel, there was no evidence of commingling, diversion, or misuse of corporate funds, no identical equitable ownership, domination, or control by equitable owners, no identification of directors and managing officers, no office sharing, and no showing of any bad faith or inequity if entities were treated separately.

Title: Crystal Towers, Ltd. v. Highlands Ins. Group, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Holding company that owned insurer's parent corporation was not liable for bad faith to insureds upon alter ego principles or under the integrated enterprise test in action alleging bad faith; the insureds failed to show such a unity of interest and ownership that an inequitable result would follow if holding company were not held liable, they failed to show day-to-day control over insurer's employment decisions or greater than normal control, and two people were common officers of both corporations.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Bad Faith and Unfair Practices. Holding company for insurer's parent corporation was not liable for insurer's alleged bad faith.

Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Officer could not be held individually liable for alleged misfeasance on part of corporation.

Headnote: Under New York law, fact that corporation was severely undercapitalized, standing alone, was insufficient reason to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Court would not pierce corporate veil to hold affiliated company liable for corporation's debts.

Title: Patin v. Thoroughbred Power Boats Inc.

Headnote: Under Florida law, district court did not clearly err in piercing the corporate veils of boat manufacturer and its successor corporation based on findings that the corporations were both alter egos of owner, and that the transformation of manufacturer to successor involved "improper conduct"; observance of corporate formalities in the transformation did not preclude piercing the corporate veils.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Court did not clearly err in piercing the corporate veils of boat manufacturer and its successor.

Title: Nat Katz & Associates, Ltd. v. Barber

Title: In re Warmus

Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Corporation's existence could not be disregarded, in lawsuit asserting a "deepening insolvency" cause of action against corporation's sole shareholders, officers, and consultants; although corporation's sole shareholders, officers, and consultants used corporation to commit a fraud, corporation was not fictional or a sham, corporate formalities were not ignored, and corporation did not lacked an identity separate from sole shareholders.

Title: C.F. Trust, Inc. v. First Flight Ltd. Partnership
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Alexandria Division.
Headnote: Under Virginia law, fact that most of the counts concerning alleged racketeering violations, conspiracy, and violations of charging or garnishment orders had been dismissed from plaintiffs' complaint did not prohibit plaintiffs from proceeding with their attempt to pierce corporate veil, even though the alter ego doctrine is not an independent cause of action but a means for complainant to reach a second corporation or individual upon a cause of action that otherwise would have existed only against the first corporation, where plaintiffs still had underlying causes of action to collect on their various judgments entered against the individual.

Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Veil of family's corporation was properly pierced.

Title: Balut v. Loral Electronic Systems
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Parent cannot be held liable for its subsidiary's civil rights violations, unless parent and subsidiary were single, integrated enterprise, that is, companies maintained (1) interrelated operations; (2) centralized control of labor relations; (3) common management; and (4) common ownership or financial control.

Title: Alside Supply Co. v. Wager
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth District, Cuyahoga County.
Headnote: For purposes of determining whether corporate fiction should be disregarded and its shareholder held liable, evidence that shareholder had complete control of corporation, that corporate formalities were not observed and that corporation was undercapitalized sufficiently showed complete dominion and control such that corporation had no separate mind, will or existence of its own.
Document Preview: Veil Piercing. Shareholder liable for debts of defunct corporation over which he exercised complete dominion and control.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: John S. Boyd Co., Inc. v. Boston Gas Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Parent companies can be held liable for CERCLA liability as operators of contaminated facility, and such liability is direct; it does not require piercing corporate veil. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 107(a)(2), 42 U.S.C.A. § 9607(a)(2).
Document Preview: The United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts, Joseph L. Tauro, Chief Judge, apportioned liability for cleanup of coal gas waste and oil gas waste under Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act (CERCLA) and Massachusetts Superfund Act, court assigned full liability to successor of gas and electric company for cleanup of coal gas waste and ordered holding company that purchased 97% of the company which manufactured coal gas, and the company's subsidiary, to pay for the cleanup of oil gas waste.  Appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Torruella, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) successor corporation was properly held responsible for coal gas waste created before any of present parties were involved with gas and electric company, and (2) court properly held holding company and subsidiary liable for the cleanup of oil gas waste. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Celi v. Canadian Occidental Petroleum Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, corporate veil would not be pierced to hold Canadian parent corporation liable for acts of American subsidiary; there was no showing that parent corporation had dominated finances, policies, and business practices of subsidiary to such extent that subsidiary had no separate existence of its own.
Document Preview: Former employee brought action against former employer and its parent corporations, claiming breach of contract, consequential damages, and promissory estoppel.  Defendants filed motion to dismiss and for summary judgment.  The District Court, Johnson, J., held that: (1) Canadian parent corporation was not subject to Court's in personam jurisdiction; (2) alleged three-year oral employment agreement was unenforceable under New York's Statute of Frauds; (3) allegations that employee had been excluded from obtaining employment in adhesives injury because defendants fraudulently induced him to leave his prior position were barred by New York's one-year limitations period for defamation; and (4) employee's alleged injuries did not arise to level of unconscionable injury required to recover under New York's promissory estoppel doctrine. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Superior Stores Co. v. Pennsylvania Dept. of Health, Special Supplemental Food Program for Women, Infants and Children
Court: Commonwealth Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Department of Health could not justify its disregard for grocery store's corporate status and thus it improperly considered past food stamp program's sanctions against sole proprietor in evaluating corporation's new store application, despite consent order which stated that it was binding on successors and transferees of sole proprietor; terms of consent order delineated how judgment against sole proprietor was to be paid but did not refer to underlying conduct which caused her to be penalized and therefore, provision binding transferees of sole proprietor would only obligate them to pay any part of judgment left unsatisfied by sole proprietor.
Document Preview: SOCIAL SERVICES - WIC. Corporation owning grocery store was entitled to participate in WIC program.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: U.S. v. BCCI Holdings (Luxembourg), S.A.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Corporation was alter ego of corporate defendant in RICO action given frequent commingling of property and business affairs of corporation and defendant, financial dependence of corporation on defendant and related entities, commonality of ownership and management of corporation and defendant, and sharing of same building, business logo, telex, post office box, and telephone line for facsimile with defendant, and given that corporation, defendant, and their sibling and parent corporations appeared to have conducted their affairs as single entity without clearly identifying which company or entity was concerned with or responsible for any particular transaction.
Document Preview: Government moved to include additional property in forfeiture order in RICO action. The District Court, Joyce Hens Green, J., held that: (1) bank accounts, proceeds from sale of condominium, legal fund, and claim filed in bankruptcy proceeding were forfeitable; (2) assets of racketeering corporation's alter ego are forfeitable interests; and (3) corporation was alter ego of racketeering corporations. Forfeiture ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Walter v. Holiday Inns, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Under New Jersey law of alter ego liability, parent corporation, rather than subsidiary that entered into partnership formed to construct casino, owed fiduciary duties to other partners; parent was true entity behind subsidiary, and control by parent over subsidiary was absolute.
Document Preview: Former partners in partnership formed to construct casino brought action against corporate partner who bought out their interests.  On corporate partner's motion for judgment as matter of law, the District Court, Rodriguez, J., held that: (1) plaintiffs were not entitled to rescission of buyout transaction; (2) corporate partner did not have duty to disclose relevant information to plaintiffs after its relationship with them became adversarial; (3) corporate partner did not violate any fiduciary duty to disclose material information; and (4) plaintiffs were not entitled to award of punitive damages with regard to their fraud claims. Motion granted in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: In re Parton
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Piercing of corporate veil was justified, where debtor was president, sole officer, and sole shareholder of corporation, debtor governed all or substantially all affairs of corporation, corporation failed to issue any stock, debtor personally paid obligations of corporation on one or more occasions and corporation paid personal obligations of debtor on one or more occasions, debtor used corporate assets for his personal use, and debtor furnished all of corporation's capital.
Document Preview: Bank commenced adversary proceeding in Chapter 7 case, seeking determination that debt was nondischargeable.  Bank moved for summary judgment.  The Bankruptcy Court, R. Guy Cole, Jr., J., held that: (1) piercing of corporate veil was justified; (2) debt was not nondischargeable on grounds of false pretenses, false representation, or actual fraud; (3) relationship between debtor and bank under agreement whereby debtor arranged leases for motor vehicles while bank provided related financial services was not fiduciary, for nondischargeability purposes; and (4) debt was not nondischargeable on grounds of willful and malicious injury. Motion granted in part and denied in part.

Title: Lorkowski v. J.C. Pitman Co., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: Parent corporation could not be held liable for any acts of wholly-owned subsidiary; although boards of directors of the two corporations overlapped, in all other respects corporation had not disregarded subsidiary's corporate separateness, had not involved itself directly in management of subsidiary and had not otherwise dominated or controlled subsidiary.
Document Preview: Action was brought against subsidiary and its parent corporation. The Supreme Court, Erie County, Ostrowski, J., denied parent corporation's motion for summary judgment.  Parent corporation appealed.  The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that parent corporation could not be held liable for acts of wholly-owned subsidiary. Reversed, motion granted, complaint and cross claims dismissed.

Title: Riggins v. Dixie Shoring Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate veil could not be pierced to render employee of corporation liable for claims against corporation; piercing of veil was effective only to reach individual assets of shareholders. LSA-R.S. 12:92, subd. D, 12:93, subd. D.
Document Preview: Homeowners sued for damages arising from allegedly negligent levelling of house.  The Civil District Court, Parish of Orleans, Max N. Tobias, Jr., J., entered judgment for owners against individuals involved with corporation which had provided services.  Appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeal, Becker, J., held that: (1) corporate veil was properly pierced to reach individual assets of major shareholder of corporation; (2) corporate veil could not be pierced to reach assets of person who was mere employee; and (3) homeowners were entitled to mental anguish damages. Affirmed in part; reversed in part. Armstrong, J., dissented and filed written reasons.

Title: In re Woodstock Associates I, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Corporations which subleased nursing homes were not alter egos of leasing corporations, though corporations were incorporated within three weeks of each and had identical officers and directors, absent showing that sublessees failed to maintain separate corporate records or observe corporate formalities, or that corporations commingled their funds or were undercapitalized.
Document Preview: Debtor nursing home operators objected to creditor's claims. On cross motions for summary judgment, the Bankruptcy Court, John H. Squires, J., held that: (1) creditor did not have perfected security interest in debtors' medicaid reimbursements; (2) creditor's postpetition contributions were not entitled to administrative priority status; and (3) issue of material fact as to whether operators' Chapter 11 plan was proposed in good faith precluded summary judgment for creditor. Debtors' motion granted in part and denied in part; creditor's motion denied.

Title: U.S. v. Kayser-Roth Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Rhode Island.
Headnote: A parent corporation that controls the management and operations of its wholly owned subsidiary can be held responsible for its subsidiary's CERCLA liability without piercing the corporate veil. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 101 et seq., as amended, 42 U.S.C.A. § 9601 et seq.
Document Preview: The United States brought suit under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liablity Act to recover cleanup costs occasioned by the discharge of trichloroethylene by a textile manufacturer.  The District Court, Francis J. Boyle, Chief Judge, held that: (1) evidence established that former parent of manufacturer was an operator for purposes of CERCLA; (2) former parent was also an owner for purposes of CERCLA; and (3) evidence established a causal connection between manufacturer's release of trichloroethylene and residential well contamination. So ordered.

Title: Gershuny v. Martin McFall Messenger Anethesia Professional Ass'n
Court: Supreme Court of Florida.
Headnote: Professional service corporation was a legal corporate entity separate and distinct from the persons comprising it. West's F.S.A. § 621.07.
Document Preview: Malpractice action was brought against professional service corporation which employed nurse anesthetist.  Judgment was entered on verdict in favor of the association, but its request for attorney fees was denied.  The District Court of Appeal, 528 So.2d 1206, reversed.  The Supreme Court, Kogan, J., held that because nurse who administered anesthesia to patient was acting independently and not under the direct supervision of any physician, none of the physician shareholders of the professional corporation which employed her could be held liable, so that statute providing for award of attorney fees to prevailing party in medical malpractice action against a physician was inapplicable. Decision of district court quashed.

Title: Reflectone, Inc. v. Farrand Optical Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
Headnote: Neither subsidiary's grant of security interest in its assets to its parent nor the cutoff of funds from the parent to the subsidiary justified piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: Plaintiff in action for breach of contract appealed from order of the United States District Court for the Middle District of Florida, No. 87427CIV T15B, William J. Castagna, J., which granted summary judgment for parent corporation after ordering arbitration as to subsidiary.  The Court of Appeals held that: (1) it was not an abuse of discretion to grant motion for summary judgment prior to discovery; (2) plaintiff was not entitled to respond to prior summary judgment motion in light of its amended complaint where amended complaint presented no genuine issues of material fact; and (3) there was no basis for piercing corporate veil. Affirmed.

Title: Geringer v. Wildhorn Ranch, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Corporate alter ego theory would be applied to impose liability on owner of corporation in view of his domination and control of the corporation, his business cards which represented that he was the owner of corporation property, his use of funds from another corporation to make purchases for the corporation, and his personal involvement with the instrumentalities which caused the harm to the plaintiffs.
Document Preview: Widow and mother of resort guests who died in boating accident brought action against the resort, its owner, and others.  Following jury verdict in favor of plaintiff, the District Court, Sherman G. Finesilver, Chief Judge, held that: (1) evidence warranted application of the corporate alter ego doctrine; (2) punitive damages could be awarded against corporation which was found negligent, even though zero percent of the negligence was attributed to it; and (3) Colorado premises liability statute does not apply to act of landowner in supplying chattel to an invitee. Ordered accordingly. See also 706 F.Supp. 1452.

Title: Chaney v. Godfrey
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Informal meetings by three 25% shareholders without sending notice, general failure to keep minutes, and failure to reduce corporate resolutions to writing unless required by financial institutions did not indicate that shareholders in corporation were acting as one and did not justify piercing of corporate veil.
Document Preview: Prospective purchasers of corporate assets brought action against shareholders to recover for breach of contract.  The First Judicial District Court, Parish of Caddo, Jeffrey P. Victory, J., rejected purchasers' claims.  Purchasers appealed.  The Court of Appeal, Sexton, J., held that: (1) letter of intent to sell corporate assets was not valid contract; (2) circumstances did not justify piercing of corporate veil; and (3) board chair and corporate secretary did not have apparent authority to sign contract for sale of assets. Affirmed.

Title: Federal Sav. and Loan Ins. Corp. v. Quality Inns, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: Related corporation would not be held liable for wrongdoings of corporations which acted as managing agent on ski resort construction project, absent evidence that related corporation operated as same organization as other corporations, that related corporation undertook to act on behalf of construction lender, or that related corporation played significant role in either relationship between other corporations and lender or relationship between other corporations and party constructing project; no fraud had been perpetrated by related corporation, nor was there paramount equity sufficient to enable district court to ignore separate corporate status of related corporation.
Document Preview: Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, as receiver for construction lender, brought action against corporations which acted as managing agent of ski resort construction project and related corporation for breach of fiduciary duty, conversion, and breach of escrow agreement.  The District Court, Joseph H. Young, J., held that: (1) managing agent had agency relationship with construction lender; (2) managing agent breached fiduciary duty owed construction lender by misapplying draw approved for furniture and fixtures; (3) managing agent was liable for portion of draw which would have been available to purchase furniture and fixtures and simple interest thereon; and (4) related corporation could not be held liable for wrongdoings of managing agent. Ordered accordingly.

Title: Arizona Public Service Co. v. Arizona Corp. Com'n
Court: Court of Appeals of Arizona, Division 1, Department B.
Headnote: Corporate "veil" would not be "pierced," for purpose of finding that parent of public utility was itself a public service corporation, where both parent and subsidiary maintained separate corporate identities and there was no evidence of undercapitalization, fraud, misconduct, or impropriety in management or operation of the two companies.
Document Preview: Public service corporation and its parent corporation sought review of order of Arizona Corporation Commission requiring them to submit detailed monthly reports concerning their past business activities and future plans.  The Superior Court, Maricopa County, Cause No. C547409, Frank T. Galati, J., granted summary judgment for Commission, and corporations appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Haire, J., held that: (1) Commission lacked jurisdiction to order parent corporation to comply with reporting requirements; (2) reporting requirement was justified, reasonable in scope, reasonably articulated, and not unduly intrusive insofar as it applied to public service corporation; and (3) corporations were not denied procedural due process when order was issued. Affirmed in part, reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Mitchell v. Rancho Viejo, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi-Edinburg.
Headnote: Corporation was not alter ego of 80% shareholder of corporation; there was no evidence to show corporation was used by shareholder to perpetrate fraud, void effect of statute, evade existing obligation, protect crime, achieve or perpetrate a monopoly, or justify a wrong, nor was there evidence to show separateness of corporation had ceased or that adherence to corporation friction would sanction fraud or foster injustice.
Document Preview: Owners of lots in subdivision brought action for declaratory judgment setting forth their rights vis-a-vis owner of certain large areas within subdivision.  The 197th District Court, Cameron County, Darrell B. Hester, J., entered judgment that denied all parties damages against each other and set forth declarations as to rights and obligations of parties in subdivision, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Dorsey, J., held that: (1) certificate of dedication which provided that owners dedicated all streets, easements, alleys and parks for use in benefit of owners and residents of subdivision did not constitute dedication of large areas in question, and (2) corporation was not alter ego of 80% shareholder of corporation which owned land in question. Judgment affirmed.

Title: Francis v. Beaudry
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Where remaining stockholders of corporations sold all assets of corporation and retained proceeds for themselves individually, corporation was "denuded" of its assets, and remaining stockholders were liable to estate of deceased stockholder for value of his holdings as of time of his death.
Document Preview: Estate of deceased stockholder brought action against remaining stockholders and directors of corporation to recover value of decedent's holdings in corporation as of date of his death.  The Probate Court No. 1, Dallas County, Nikki DeShazo, J., found in favor of estate, and stockholder appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Devany, J., held that: (1) remaining stockholders were personally liable to estate, where remaining stockholders continued to operate corporation for their own benefit after decedent's death and ignored existence of corporate form; (2) probate court had subject matter jurisdiction of cause; and (3) trial court erroneously included sum twice in its calculations of total net assets of corporation. Affirmed as reformed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Futch v. Head
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, First District.
Headnote: Real estate corporations owned by broker were not distinct from broker, and, thus, corporate veil could be pierced, where broker merged corporations' liabilities and assets with personal funds, failed to distinguish between individual and corporate capacities in connection with sale of property along with cobroker, and paid commission to one corporation upon sale of her property.
Document Preview: Cobroker brought action against broker for payment of commission and fraud. The Circuit Court, Escambia County, Lacey A. Collier, J., awarded damages for breach of contract and conversion and awarded treble damages under Anti-Fencing Act.  Broker appealed.  The District Court of Appeal, Shivers, J., held that: (1) enforceable contract existed between broker and cobroker to pay cobroker portion of broker's 20% interest in sold property in order to compensate cobroker for efforts as joint venturer; (2) existence of contract negated any trebling of damages, regardless of whether conversion existed; and (3) cobroker was procuring cause entitled to commission. Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Carlson v. Carlson
Court: Court of Appeals of Minnesota.
Headnote: Trial court in dissolution action properly pierced corporate veil of husband's professional association where husband had not respected separate identity of personal and corporate assets, despite contention that corporate veil was improperly pierced because no finding of alter ego was made.
Document Preview: Husband appealed from judgment of dissolution entered in the District Court, Hennepin County, Sheryl Hvass, J.  The Court of Appeals, Popovich, C.J., held that: (1) trial court erred in its division of marital property, and (2) trial court did not abuse its discretion in failing to recuse itself given lack of demonstrated prejudice. Affirmed in part, reversed in part and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Molander v. Raugust-Mathwig, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 3, Panel Four.
Headnote: Finding of personal knowledge on behalf of corporation's principal with respect to inaccurate letter did not provide basis for imposing personal liability on principal; failure of principal to warn recipient that an erroneous letter had been issued causing the recipient to take action to his detriment was not sufficient to warrant disregard of corporate form and impose personal liability.
Document Preview: Architect brought action for fee.  The Superior Court, Spokane County, John J. Lally and William Luscher, JJ., entered judgment in favor of architect, and principal of one corporation appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Thompson, J., held that: (1) failure to form limited partnership resulted in general partnership liability of corporate entities which were to form the limited partnership, not in liability of corporate principal personally; (2) failure of corporate principal to inform architect of errors in letter sent to him by corporation did not provide basis for imposing personal liability; and (3) principal of corporation had not been unjustly enriched. Reversed. McInturff, J., dissented and filed opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: L.B. Industries, Inc. v. Smith
Court: United States District Court, D. Idaho.
Headnote: It would be unfair to subject innocent corporate directors to liability for unscrupulous conduct of a single director who, as president, had operated company as if he and it were one and the same.
Document Preview: Action was brought against minority shareholder in corporation and its representative on the board of directors for alleged fraudulent transactions involving the purchase and development of small hydroelectric sites.  The District Court, Ryan, J., held that: (1) under Idaho law, minority shareholder and its representative would not be liable for any fraud committed by corporation, and (2) corporate entity could not be disregarded to impose personal liability on minority shareholder or its representative. Judgment accordingly.

Title: Kashfi v. Phibro-Salomon, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: "Collaborative activity" between related corporations did not present adequate grounds for piercing corporate veil.
Document Preview: Iranian citizen brought action to recover payment for services he claimed to have rendered in Iran for Delaware corporation.  On corporation's motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Tenney, J., held that: (1) written personal services contract, under which citizen arranged meetings between corporation and key officials of Iranian Government in connection with oil barter transaction, was between citizen and British subsidiary of corporation; (2) British subsidiary was not subservient to corporation so as to permit piercing of corporate veil between the corporations; (3) citizen's quantum meruit claim for finder's fee for having introduced corporation to Iranian officials was barred by New York six-year limitations period; and (4) contract violated Iranian penal statute and contravened public policy of United States and, thus, was unenforceable. Motion granted.

Title: Kashfi v. Phibro-Salomon, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: British subsidiary corporation was not subservient to Delaware parent corporation, so as to permit piercing of corporate veil between the two corporations, but rather was one corporation of group of related corporations, in different countries, working closely together, where subsidiary had separate board of directors, had its own bank account, had its own credit standing, maintained separate offices, was separately managed, and conducted its business affairs separate from that of parent.

On corporation's motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Tenney, J., held that: (1) written personal services contract, under which citizen arranged meetings between corporation and key officials of Iranian Government in connection with oil barter transaction, was between citizen and British subsidiary of corporation; (2) British subsidiary was not subservient to corporation so as to permit piercing of corporate veil between the corporations; (3) citizen's quantum meruit claim for finder's fee for having introduced corporation to Iranian officials was barred by New York six-year limitations period; and (4) contract violated Iranian penal statute and contravened public policy of United States and, thus, was unenforceable. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Paynesville Farmers Union Oil Co. v. Ever Ready Oil Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Minnesota.
Headnote: Trial court correctly refused to pierce corporate veil of closely held corporation and hold two sole shareholders personally liable on theory that corporation was allegedly alter ego or instrumentality of shareholders, even though corporation depreciated property owned by the sole shareholders which they leased to corporation and there was no documentation of sale of some assets from the preexisting sole proprietorship to the corporation, where annual meetings were held, minutes were taken, separate bank accounts were kept, one dividend was paid, annual salaries were set, business was not undercapitalized, sole shareholders did not siphon funds and in fact when corporation was faltering shareholders took as draws less than they were entitled to as salary, and there was no evidence that corporation was operated as a constructive fraud or in an unjust manner.
Document Preview: Petroleum business appealed from judgment of the District Court, Stearns County, Paul J. Doerner, J., which refused to hold sole shareholders of closely held corporation liable on debt owed by corporation to petroleum business.  The Court of Appeals, Lansing, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to support finding that closely held corporation was a disclosed principal, and (2) trial court correctly refused to pierce corporate veil and hold sole shareholders personally liable. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Dorton v. Dorton
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Finding that president of a corporation who was also a director and 51% shareholder mismanaged corporate property by allowing it to deteriorate and not realizing full rental potential from it was properly considered as one of several factors demonstrating domination and control of corporation to detriment of minority shareholder.
Document Preview: Equitable distribution order was entered by District Court, Durham County, David Q. LaBarre, C.J., after earlier actions concerning custody, alimony, and child support, and divorce were consolidated by stipulation of husband and wife.  Wife appealed. Title: Nelson v. Control Systems Intern., Inc.
